number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												My take on Master of Orion... the new one.As a space-based 4X, it's pretty cool.As a Master of Orion... it falls short in a number of places.Let's compare it first to Master of Orion 2.  The... after much debate... champion of MoO.  The one that everyone, for generations, continued to look back at as the "Legendary" game when it came to space 4X.Master of Orion 2 not only made sense in what it did, but it had a tactical combat system that was unparralelled at the time, and often attempted, but never matched to.  When Master of Orion 3 came out, one of the major complaints was that the tactical combat was no longer available.This tactical combat system is part of what made MoO and MoO2 so legendary, and what broke the series when MoO3 came out and disappointed people, (I know... I was there when it came out.  Installed it and tried it and went back to MoO2.)The fact that the new MoO has decided to leave all tactical combat to real time strategy combat makes it no different than... say... Sins of a Solar Empire.  It has, instead of embracing Master of Orion's winning module, embraced today's game expectations.  Instead, the level of tactical combat that is available has put your combat control just a step above Endless Space, (I play a lot of these kinds of games,) but at about the level of Sword of the Stars.  Making it... just another space 4X game.In MoO2, your planets grew at a believable rate.  To have adequite food meant that nobody was starving.  The planet thrived, and about every 5 turns you'd get another population.  To have less than adequite food, the growth would be lowered, and with enough negative, would become starvation.  In new MoO, it takes after games like Civilization, Endless Space, and such, where now the excess food suddenly means more people reproduce.  Does gluttany = sex?  It does not.  This makes sense, perhaps, in a single city setting, where on the level of food means that just enough people are adequitely fed, but still not everyone.  Yet, planetary?  This food format does not makes sense.  Yes, it is a game, and this is a game mechanic, but this is a space (sci-fi) game, and much of it should be based off of science.In MoO2, (and even in games like Endless Space,) the more your ships fight, the more experience they gain, and they gain bonuses to attack and defense.  You can also recruit leaders for your planets and your ships.  NewMoO?  Not so much.  In fact, there is no such thing as ship experience, uniquely upgrading single ships, or, in fact, leaders.In MoO2, and this is sort of a tactical combat thing, you could disable your enemy ships.  Take out their engines, their systems... and then raid them with your crew and capture the ships.  This happens all the time in sci-fi movies, and is probably one of my favorite features from MoO2 that just about every other game is missing out on... including every other Master of Orion.I don't think I need to go on as to how NewMoO is not living up to the ideal of Master of Orion.All that being said, it is a good game.  It's worth checking out.  It has upsides and downsides in comparison to the other 4Xs of todays generation.  I have played this, Endless Space, Sword of the Stars, Sins of a Solar Empire, and many other space 4X games.  Today's space 4Xs all feel very similar.  This and Endless Space are both currently at the top of my list for MoO2 replacements.Oh, but I don't have to replace it anymore.  It's now playable through Steam!  So I no longer need any of them... do I?Ah, but alas, MoO2's difficulty is at the high end of the bell curve.  So you'd all better be wary of it, if you intend to try it for the first time.  When I was a young teen, I would play it non-stop for weeks.  My own personal empire dominating the galaxy, or falling before those damn Psilons taking over the council.

content:
Posted: March 16
												I have thousands of hours on Master of Orion 1, hundreds on Master of Orion 2 and thousands more on Master of Orion 3. This one is a disappointment. The human and khanate voices are parodies, and GNN a once nice part of the game, is so horrid, I disable it before every game.The tech trade is messed up. You can research some things, but anything you steal won't actually speed up your own research, a major point in the earlier versions. The fights ... have potential, but it's horribly wasted with such poor angles that i'd rather watch the battle from top to judge weapon efficiency instead of just enjoying it.The AI is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, as is the planetary governor (although in it's defense there are loads of useless buldings). Had one game where I'd receive a bribe to start, get a bribe to make peace, then repeat the cycle 4-5 times without damaging my relations.Since population growth is so slow, you can actually camp pirates, bomb them, then wait for them to respawn over and over.Wars are irritating since the AI sends massive fleets to your border, and just before it blasts your planet or outpost to bits, it declares war. To top it off, you don't get a "Threatening fleet detected" (as you did in MOO 1, when any fleet heading for your systems would show up in bright red!), but you do get it for those irritating space whale dragons things.I hated XCom when it came out because it changed the brand so much, but on it's own it still was a good game and it's sequel proved it, but this ... this brand is just dead.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20
												First off: this is a great game, ignore all the naysayers.This game maintains the ambience and feel of the old Master of Orion series whilst still providing a much improved and modernized UI.A lot of people criticise the choice to use star lanes from MOO3 instead of the fly anywhere  within range ability from MOO1&2.  Since most people skipped MOO3 this is a departure from what they remembered from MOo2.It's neither a superior or inferior solution but presents a different set of strategies.  With star lanes you can set up choke points, you can build military outposts and more physically define your species borders.  It's not "realistic" but neither are space bears, it's a game and it adds an interesting strategic layer.The graphics, the voice acting, the humour is all there; although seeing the same joke for the 3rd or 4th or 100th time loses the eventual appeal.The AI isn't the smartest, but there are multiple difficult levels and for anyone wanting a real challenge they can create a custom race and give themselves any handicap they like.For those coming from MOO2, the AI is no worse than in that game.  It is a lot more trusting than the AI in Civilization and a lot less likely to act in bizarre random ways.   Unlike civ if you've got a good relationship and a non aggression pact, trading and research agreements in MOO you're not likely to be declared war on by that species. I've not encountered any bugs in two play throughs.Very good game can't wait for the sequel now the current team have experience.  In the original series MOO2 improved dramatically over MOO1 and this one is already good and will keep me occupied for many many hours.  I have a feeling this will be one of the games I keep replaying over the upcoming years, always on rotation.  Ignore the people who complain this isn't identical to the game from their childhood, you see them on every reboot, it doesn't mean the game isn't good.

Posted: August 31, 2016
												If you played Civ 5 and MOO 2 then you will find the new MOO to be a complete mix of these two. Diplomacy is mostly copied from Civ 5 (earlier Civs had different diplomacy), the rest is pure MOO2 in almost every sense. This makes the gameplay very familiar straight from the get go.The diplomacy, contrary to Civ 5 actually makes sense (AI don´t backstab you 3 turns after they propose a declaration of friendship). Although you can read the AI´s intentions pretty easily in Civ5 after 20+ games.This, together with excellent voice casting and lines, makes for a very good game 8/10 because there could be more races available.Also the depth is not THAT deep, but for a player with limited time this game is just right.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												TL;DR: This is the first actual MoO2 remake that's both faithful and modern.I'm an old-school MoO fan, having played hundreds of hours of both MoO and MoO2. No 4X since MoO2 has captured me like that game did, because they all made fundamental mistakes or oversights.I did not have high hopes for this game, because the previews looked bad, but I was very, very pleasantly surprised. This game actually does have the MoO2 spirit, and almost all of the important stuff is there. The radical race differences, the simple yet effective economy, the ship design, the battles - it's all there. Some of it is streamlined, in particular the battles, but for the most part the important bits are intact.If I had to complain, it would be that they went slightly too far in the streamlining of the tactical battles. Realtime is fine, there's a wide variety of weapons and modules, and taking control of the battle does make a difference (particularly whenever torpedoes are involved), but I just wish they would have kept the shield quadrants, the subsystem damage and the ability to board ships.Other than that minor complaint, this game is great. Aggressive AI, a big and interesting tech tree with almost all the old MoO2 techs, hugely different races (telepathic and tolerant is out, but lithovore and creative is still in!), all in a very polished and neat package. Definitely recommended.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												This game is not perfect, it has some warts.  But, I really like this game and do recommend it.It is about 75% perfect, which is not bad.  The remaining 25% is not horrid, just not ideal.  The "off-putting" bits are some features from the old game which I wish it had not changed with so much of a nod towards a civilization type game.If you want the old Moo II game you can get it as part of the bundle.  It is a masterful work and so I recommend this bundle above all.The game plays quickly and smoothly.  No load issues, no performance issues, and much better than typical crash issues (Civ 6 crashes more often, for comparison).There is no scream out at you "wrong" item.  Just some that have room for improvement, which while less than perfect is far from a "don't buy this" flaw.Top wished for feature is that it remembers your last settings.  It doesn't.  So create your favorite custom race over and over.Next I would love some sort of hero system (would even pay for a DLC to add this).I like the ship design tool.  I like the option to auto upgrade.  I would like it extended to custom ships (just apply the same logic to them).I dislike the fact that the ships have unlimited range.   So I typically play on "spiral universe" which puts red jump lanes in which can not by used until mid to late game.There are about 1/2 dozen "nearly identical" games to this out now.  Sadly I own them all.  This one despite the flaws is the most fun to play.I read several of the negative reviews (and a few of the positive ones) before I wrote this.  Many of them raised as problems what I thought of as quibbles.  Meaning that while I typically agreed with them the issues raised did not detract  enough to move this space 4x down the list as best of breed for me.

content:

												I bought this game early Access, because I wanted a MoO in modern Tech. I very much disliked the "Realtime"- Fights, that eliminate a lot of the tactical depth I loved in MoO 2, but well, i coped with it, because thats just the Times (I never ever found a RTS thats not dumped down compared to TBS, because otherwise it would be just to hard to beat a fast reacting machine). On the other hand I loved the atmosphere, the voiceacting and the music are great, graphics are nice, so overall, it was a nice game and I played for the sake of my memories of the good old games of my young adulthood.Then I saw three new races and wanted to give this another go - maybe the game would be "ready" now and the combat would feel like I have an actual impact on the outcome? And maybe I could play with the Elerians, my number two race of MoO2 (first was a slighltly adjusted Klackon without the uncreativ feat and less production-bonus).But NO! I Have to pay for it! I already payed 40 Euros for an unfinished game, because I loved the old Games, but I wont support this stupid milking policies the gaming industries are constantly doing any more. And I recommed You and every other customer out there should do the same.I realy, realy hope this review helps dropping selling numbers for this title, at least as long as they dont change their policies. I wont pay 50 Bugs or more for a simple reboot, no matter how good the voiceacting is.DO NOT SUPOORT THIS!(plz notice English is NOT my natural Language, mistakes will happen)

number of helpful: 80 of 158 people (51%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								I payed only an arm for this game, I still have my leg. If you are a fan of Moo 2 don't buy this game. The devs want to make this a carbon copy of the first Moo game with some minor extras but have no plans of implementing the things that set Moo2 apart and made it one of the greatest 4x games of all time. They have incorporated aspects of less successful modern games (for instance limiting travel to fixed waypoints to bottleneck and lengthen space travel LAME). They stole some concepts from other games like civ which probably add to the game in a good way but this definitely does not feel like Moo. No turn based combat, they stated in forums that it is hard to do it in 3D, as if thats even relevant......just do a 3D rendering on a 2d plain and don't ruin a great concept. I waited 20 years to be disappointed. They have limited race customization over concerns of balance to a point where it defeats the purpose. Don't get me started on the tech tree, shoulda built on the Moo2 platform for that instead of stealing the boring linear concept from the Civ genre. I waited 4 patches before writing this review to give them a chance to improve the game but it just keeps getting worse. My perception of the situation at this point is that the devs here are your typical "I want to make my mark" type of people and as a result they are a detrement to themselves. You know the thing about the wheel is that it does not need to be reinvented. As soon as they start incorporating features from Moo2 this review will change. Until then im going to move forward with the belief that I was tricked into buying a game that had no intention of ever being true to form. BAH HUMBUG!A quick update. The way they just changed how food works is awful. Just awful. cant produce anything because my 1 colonist on new settlements HAS to produce food or they will starve? Are you Sh***ing me? An advanced space fairing race that can literally travel between stars has to fully commit to farming to survive? Really? Are you trying to make the game even more cumbersome?

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Quick&Dirty:Got this game a few days ago at a christmas discount and had good fun with it, making my own little space empires but in the end the AI can't put up a fight, which ultimately gives the game little challenge. My playthroughs:I first went into the tutorial and got the game explained to me, but the game was so easy I thought it must be set to a low difficulty setting for the tutorial. I restarted on normal difficulty, but after easily bumrushing my nearest neighbour I restarted on the very hard difficulty and downloaded a balance mod (yay modding!). While the other races put up a bit of a fight in the opening moves of the game, by the mid-game I had a fleet that could crush anything thrown against it, mostly because I had super-large ships, while the enemy was still toying around with flea-sized ships. By then I realised that the game is wonderfully worked out and a good fun space empire sim, but the AI is simply too weak to keep up with an intelligent human player, even if the difficulty setting gives them a resource advantage. This is a pity and ultimately what turns me away from the game, but before I got there I spent a decent amount of hours playing. Looking back, I got value for my money, so this game gets a thumbs up from me.The good:Good voiceacting (they really went all-in on the famous actors).Distinct races.Lots of empire-building fun.Active devs (so there's hope for the future!)The bad:Poor AI: This is what cripples the game currently for me. The AI can't put up a decent fight, spitting out little ships and measly fleets mid-endgame while my fleet has multiple titans, each of which is capable of wiping out the enemy single-handedly. But it also extends into diplomacy (really bad trades), ship customization and empire expansion. The AI is just not up to the task.Verdict:I enjoyed my little space-empire building frenzy. Sure, the AI couldn't put up much of a fight, but I had fun exploring and empire-building and fighting huge space-monsters. I got value for my money (game was discounted) and if you have run out of games to play and nothing new is on the horizon, you can pick up this game to fill the gap. It's not the best, but it's good fun for a while.Tip:The Space Amoeba stats are a lie.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												As one of the many long time fans of the MOO franchise I have to say this is the single best version I have ever played.This is not a clone of any of the previous titles, rather its done in the same style and foundation with many more optimizations and fun additions.  Not every singleplayer game has to take a dozen hours, with the wide array of customization options you can engineer a campaign that lasts one gaming session or one that can last days.  Your choice.Like most of the MOO title technology trumps all so the Psylon are still the goto race for most players, but if you don't choose that race you can still do well in a singleplayer campaign provided you stick to your racial strongpoints.There is still alot of work that can be done and optimization to come (lithovores come to mind, nothing in the game is designed to accept a player race with lithovore trait yet) however the game is READY TO PLAY at this time.So if you like space turn-based strategy and tons of empire customisation options this is a no brainer of a buy.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												If you want to know why you should not waste money on this game, look no further than the pirates.They don't pirate. I know the pirates in earlier games weren't amazing, either, but by now the pirates should have some function other than "screw up the early game".That's all they do, literally. And this is the design philosophy for this game: add something to slow down progression, otherwise the game is too easy.The pirates never pirate. They don't take anything. They destroy everything they can, and otherwise just provide fodder for no reason. There's no diplomatic interaction with the pirates, even tho it seems an obvious idea to be able to buy them off or pay them to attack an enemy, etc. Nope. They are just randomly spawning units that fly directly to their death over and over until they've sufficiently weakened your defender to kill it.It's so damned *boring* and predictable and not fun. Anti-fun, if you will.If you're not convinced by that, then consider the pollution mechanic. It's literally just a time waster. You must micro-manage pollution on your planets, even planets with next to nothing in the way of industry.I mean JESUS people, I get it, you want some internet karma for caring about the environment - that's great. I am really impressed that the devs are SJWs out to clean up the lakes and rivers, but this is a game set in a technologically advanced universe. Why can't we use alternate forms of energy? Why can't we use clean production processes? Why must you beat me over the head with your tired politics?Just. No.Just save your money - the bad design choices and political nonsense just aren't worth the price of admission.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												This would be a fine introduction to the 4X genre if you have a friend you'd like to get into the hobby.That said,  some of my finest gaming memories are playing the original MOO and MOO2 back in my misspent youth, so I'm a bit more of a grizzled stellar emperor, and my standards are demanding.We've had a bit of an abundance of riches after a decade long drought-- one thinks immediately of Stellaris-- which layers on substantially more complexity and depth.   There's also the absolutely amazing Endless Space series, which is crafted amazingly well.  So MOO has some rather stiff competition these days.By those standards, is this title a success?   Well-- yes, and no.   The production values are absolutely first rate.   The game looks gorgerous.   The sound design and voice acting is also first rate.   Which is something you normally do not associate with a 4X title.The no comes from the depth of gameplay-- I won a 10 hour campaign on Hard with basically one hand tied behind my back.   There were no surprises-- which was very disappointing-- the Klackon did not, for example-- seem to prefer smaller swarm strategies, as before-- and the Bulrathi did not lean towards larger, Battleship-type fleets.   Every race basically was super nice to me until I wiped the galactic floor with them.The tech tree is almost unchanged from earlier games.   The antareans show up-- but their AI seems weird.   They sometimes start to bomb your colonies, but then change their mind and leave.   This makes them vastly less of a horrifying threat.Taken holistically, this is a satisfying nostalgia purchase at its price point.  I'm happy another generation will get to enjoy some MOOOOOOOOO addiction.

												Better than the reviews would have you believe. Not as complex as a game like Stellaris, but well polished, and confident game that leans on a good foundation. At this point the game seems largely complete, (Dec 31 2016). The combat is good and the game has some great roleplay capacity, as the races are fairly well fleshed out. Additionally, the game has soul, with planet destroying superweapons, an interesting espionage system, col looking ships, and nifty ground battles. The diplomacy system functions, though on normal difficulty no one seems particularly aggressive. I'd recommend it for anyone who enjoys 4x, and as an introductory 4x game this is probably the title for you. I look forward to playing more.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												MOO4 is a nice return to the franchise.  It really plays very similar to MOO2, without the Antarians attacking randomly.The micromanaging of your colonies is made fairly easy via the way events are presented each turn.MOO4, which by the way, I really wish the folks behind the game just called it MOO4 to avoid confusion.  It's ok to have lots of sequels, look at Final Fantasy!  Anyway, MOO4 swaps out the MOO2-turn based space combat engine to a RTS style engine found in any other game of this genre.  The cinematic camera in the space combat is annoyingly bad, with no way to control camera, or battle.  Top down seems the best way to watch space battles and naturally it never ceases to entertain to watch large fleets unleash death upon each other.Overall MOO4 feels and plays a lot like MOO2 in my opinion.  It doesn't really bring much new to the table in terms of comparison to MOO2, but at least it's copying from a proven game.  All the familiar races and elements, right down to the types of random events feels taken straight from MOO2.It gets my thumbs up, because it's just as fun as MOO2, but I gotta say, I hope this series evolves if they plan to offer addons or another game (MOO5.)  If you liked MOO2, it's almost certain you'll like this, it's nearly the same game.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												I've loved every Master of Orion game, including Master of Orion 3 (a game I feel gets a worse rap than it deserves) and this one. But I cannot recommend it to anyone else.If you're a fan of prior Master oF Orion games, playing this raises a lot of fun little nods to them. Everything from the reprised races from old games to the fact that the colonization music is the same tune as its MS-DOS ancestor. The people that made this game definitely knew the Master of Orion series.Other reviewers here have brought up very valid points, however, regarding how this doesn't embody the spirit of Master of Orion. No free range travel, making various drives and fuels boring and inconsequential, overall simpler. Star lanes make things very isolated, and present a very different, in a much simpler way. Technology tree is very straight forward, even if you've got the illusion of choice, you're very likely to just be picking the same tech everyone else is, and unlike the prior games you eventually can just research everything (outside of very VERY few technology categories where you pick what effect it has and have to trade with another empire that picked the other), overall the science track is much simpler. Combat is very straight forward, with none of the dynamics of missile counter measuring, and all the jazz with boarding ships with tractor beams or assault shuttles, making for a simpler tactical battle altogether.You'll notice a common theme, here... Everything's simple. Very... Easy to grasp and just click through without much thought or care.That's when I realized the real issue I have with this Master of Orion reboot. And why I also still enjoy it. It's simple. Easy. And really is just a lot of playful references to the older games.Presently, I just play the game when I'm on downtime at work, or need to break the monotony of studying. But if I want to truly sit down and enjoy a game? I'd sooner just go for Master of Orion 2. This game sooner belongs on a tablet or cell phone, with how simple it is, and I'm seriously wondering if that's the idea they had at the start.Overall, I enjoy the game. But if you want a real TBS experience, I'll much sooner recommend ANY other Master of Orion game. I'd only recommend this if you've got a laptop and barely have an hour or two to kill in a very simple 4x Strategy game that probably should've been made a tablet game.

Posted: December 24, 2016
												Master of Orion is both a massive hit and miss depending on your perspective. The game has clearly been lovingly crafted to be faithful to the original trilogy games but where it falls off is in the level of simplicity that has been incorporated into the game. This isn't necessarily a bad thing though. So what is the bad? Well when your game is sequel to another you usually expect some kind of innovation to the game's mechanics to make it new and exciting, not just a reskin. Master of Orion is at it's bare bones a reskin of Master of Orion 2 and doesn't seem to try anything new mechanically. The good though is that this game has clearly been a labour of love, from the effort put into getting iconic sci-fi voice voice actors to the universe itself constantly and enthusiastically encouraging you to expand and explore this game is very much, a good game. Unfortunately though it may fall short of your expectations of a 4x grand strategy or of a sequel.With all that said though Master of Orion is truly made for new players and makes for a great introductory point to 4x strategy. The user interface is easy to understand, doesn't clog up the display and is very elegant, the galaxy and worlds look amazing, colourful and alive, and there is exceptional voice acting to help make even the most mundane tasks enjoyable.This game is worth trying out, if you find it's too simple you can easily just ask for a Steam refund but if you do end up liking it you will find yourself engrossed in this game for hours at a time. 9/10

												I gotta say the negative reviews have me at a loss... the game is everything Moo3 should have been.  I think most of the angst spawns from the developer stopping patches.. I guess as a old gamer this is not as big an issue to me as in the day or yore we bought a CD and dealt with w/e ending up installing.  The current mindset that a game is dead just because the developers dont constantly fiddle with it is silly.  They made the game they set out to make, and now they are done. Simple as that.  Now that out of the way lets review some pro/consProsGraphicsUIGameplayease of play (you don't need a degree and 6manuals to sort what your doing)spirit of Moo firmly in placeConsSometime the AI seems so braindead its almost comicalthe thematic attempts of some of the voice actors can be a bit tiresome on a long gamemultiplayer (its turn based.. if you and your friends aren't planning a weeklong gaming session look elsewhere)Ship based combat... this is not a issue that is unique to MoO... it seems more and more that RTS and TBS games are dumming down the combat to sit back and watch the rock paper scissors simulation... tbh I hate it but thats the new norm.To summarizeis it worth 30usd?  well thats up to you but I found it so yes.  Is the game dead? not hardly just finished.  Would I recomend it?  Yes I would... its not the MoO it might have been, but you will get your moneys worth in game time and in the end thats what really matters.

Posted: January 28
												This started out as a stable, boring game. After months of patchs and changes, it is now an unstable, boring game, and kind of a mess. The developers never had a vision, they just tried to copy MOO2. The voice acting is repetitive and was a waste of talent. In some places where there should be a cut scene, an actor reads a text box about what happened. I started escaping these fairly quickly as it is just boring to hear the same thing over and over. The two things that annoy me most are: (1) the polution effect and (2) the characters representing assistants. The polution effect adds nothing positive to gameplay and is just plain aggravating. Some of the assistant characters have annoying voices, and why are they all female? The silicoid are male and female? They were neither in MOO2. None of the aliens seems all that alien. The unforgivable sin is the space combat. I want it to be turn based so I can take my time to plan tactical attacks. Space combat is supposed to be the funnest part of this game. Boring space combat is completely unacceptable. This is another area that was handled better in MOO2. This game is a paint by numbers attempt at MOO2 that fails on every level and with the changes and patches it seems to be getting worse.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								MoO is really a love or hate type of game. Do you want a full graphical & UI update for MoO2? Then leave it. Better yet: pretend it does not exist. Here are the main reasons:Combat:It lacks turn-based combat, the arena is very small, the AI of your ships is horrible in the realtime one, the AI OFF button is bugged, and you can't always select single units, only "fleets" of ships.Unit design:Now you have fixed slots (e.g.: 4 weapons, 1 propulsion, 1 computer, 1 shield, 6 special...) you can fill up to the capacity of the ship. Again, this lessens the combinations you can come up with.Research:Instead of completely separate research branches, MoO has a Civ-like tree. You can leave a few techs out, but not much. You can't specialize in one branch and then trade or steal the remainder. There are some techs that present you with a choice of a technology duo, but those are nowhere near the choices you could burden yourself with in MoO2 using the uncreative perk.AI:They all appear utterly insane so far, with absolutely zero sense of reality. I've seen better sense of it from Civilization enemies at launch date.Leaders:Completely missing functionality.Space travel:Space lanes and infinite fuel instead of fixed max distance before needing a refuel. I don't dislike this most of the time, but some might. It does make cutting off a segment of space harder and easier at the same time....I could go on with smaller nuances. Development:The main problem is, the devs stated they will not be adding turn-based combat or rewamp the research. They will add custom races, espionage, but not much else that is missing now. They created a "more accessible" game, not a successor. One without much of a character.Plus side:There are positive changes as well, for instance, I love that at the end of the game, you can reload the game from any given turn. There are voiced characters, although your advisors get annoying really, really fast. And the UI responds to the now-standardized way, although there are many, many shortcuts that are missing for a power gamer. And there is a catgirl with cleavage, if you're into that.ConclusionSo if you are a fan of old Master of Orion and want at least that complexity, go to GoG.com, buy MoO2 again, and forget this ever existed. It's way cheaper and way better.If you are new to the world of 4X space strategy games, this might be a good watered-down tutorial. Kinda like how American beers compare to European ones.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												This game is CRAP.  About the only things it has going for it are a well designed UI and a few lines of voice recordings from famous people.  Beyond that, EVERYTHING falls far short.  Graphics are cartoonish and dated.  Much info is missing from places you actually need it, such as weapon range/damage/effect/fire rate info in ship designer, or tooltips explaining what custom race picks actually do.  Pretty much everything in this game is a direct rip off of "sword of the stars", right down to the phase lanes (sorry, star lanes) and the completely useless "real time" tactical combat that actually gives you almost zero control over your fleet.  The AI is totally worthless, either you have a fleet and it does nothing, or you dont have a fleet and it declares war on you for no reason, even if you were friends.  There is nothing interesting about the galaxy at all...no minor races, no exterior threat like the dreaded hyperspace beast, no antarans....absolutely NOTHING but the dimwitted one-dimensional AI to offer you any challenge or something to do other than declare war on other races.  The tech tree is extremely limited and very few technologies are present that actually have any measurable effect on your empire.  Other reviews have gone into more detail about how this game is completely lacking in almost every area, so I won't.This game is completely unworthy of the "master of orion" name.  DO NOT spend money on this game...like me, you will regret it.  Sword of the stars is almost exactly the same game, but manages to do something that this game does not: it's actually, at times, enjoyable.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												(Edit after playing more hours.)Very disappointing.TLDR: game is oversimplified and bland.          (  the poor ship combat and loss of real weapon differnces from MOO3 is what kills it for me.)          ( Saddly in this MOO beam and mass driver weapons funcition almost identical,  Fighters bombers and missle almost identical.  Where as in MOO3 each weapon had its own unique flavor among mass driver, laser , plasma, missle, fighter, bombers intercepters.)(PROS: easy to lean and play since its so simplified.)... This game turned into an oversimplified version of master of orion 3.  I feel like this is what MOO3 would look like if you wanted to make it into a mobile app.Ship combat is stale, the battlefield is so tiny ships weapons cover a quarter of it.  Making maneuvering and scouting pointless.In MOO3 you would design ships to fit rolls in fleets including specialized point defense ships, bombers carriers, scout fleets (since the battle field was large enough that you would have to scout out enemy ships.)   The tech tree was interesting in MOO3 because each play through you would get different techs you wouldn’t get auto fire, enveloping, miniaturization,  on every weapon you would work with what you had and strategically trade for what you wanted.MOO3 had a real economic, population growth simulator not little guys you drop around 3 choices.  ( MOO has some differnce in techs with each playthrough just not the extend of MOO3 and not in weapon mods.)I don’t find the great voice acting adds to the game, the click of the klakons or beeps of the meklar conveyed just as much and gave them real personality instead of everyone speaking English. MOO3 had horrible game breaking bugs, but its scope was amazing, the creativity you could use with ship and fleet design.  The real difference in weapon functions including ranges optimal damage range accuracy fire rate for point defense was so much more interesting.In this MOO I have had the enemy ship AI go straight across the battlefield tell they hit the “wall” and just stop they didn’t even rotate to aim their front facing weapons at me multiple times. ( I have also had a couple combat freezes and large fleet battle lags)all and all MOO3 with vanilla or strawberry mod >= MOO.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												This game feels a bit like MOO for console.  Everything has been "dumbed down" The game is resonable well polished, looks good, few bugs and It would probably stand up 10 years ago.  It stands up well on its own if you have never played a 4x and don't compare it to anything.but the 4x genre has moved on, other games leave this feeling dated and incomplete.Its sad to see a game that defined the 4x for years get released like this.I find myself watching TV while playing this game.IssuesThe tech tree is very repetative with no real innovation, just 25% more +1 dmg and you don't really decide what to research you just work along the tree.   Often attepting to pickup just production and planet techs, researches everything; guns, shields etc there is no way to focus a "tree" like other games.All races share the same tech tree and have very little variation in racial traists outside 25% bonus in X to make them unique.  The one race that doesn't consume food (like every 4x these days) is the only Unique trait.The AI is hideously dumb and not very agressive, You have to try to provoke combat in most situations and then its simply a matter of defeating 2-3 fleets and GG you won. now you spend 50+ turns playing Whack-a-Mole on planets that spawn a single frigate.  The game "ends" in 1-2 turns of combat.Increasing AI difficulty simply makes them cheat and build faster.There is no real tactical depth, the Combat is very simple, the area you fight in is too small to play ranged tactics and ships respond poorly to commands, about the only tactics involved is making sure missile vollys don't overkill small ships.The "ship builder" is the most simplistic thing I have seen in almost any 4x that basically boils down to, do you want direct fire weapons or missiles and upgrade your ships armor/shields x% every tech level.Unlike most games where a well built design can outclass multiple designs of the same production value this game feels like you simply pick what colour the lines seen in combat will be.Govening is poor, when you get a large amount of planets its quickly annoying to spam production, the game stops after a build queue of 4 as if we are saving memory space for consoles? Autobuild seems to randomly pick somthing, there is no large scale tools and managing fleets is just annoying.I feel like the developers of this game need to play some "MOO clones" and implement all the innovation and amazing features that have been developed over the past 10 years.It feels more like a High rez texture pack for an old gamePros +Well polished+Simplistic for new players with good tutorial+MultiplayerCons-Simple-Dated-DullEndless spaceSpace empires VAlpha CentauriSword of the stars 1,2Gal civ  2,3PredestinationStardrive 1,2StelarisStarpoint GeminiStar Rular 2All offer much moreIf you have never played a 4x "moo clone" before this is a good tutorial introduction to the genre.if you want a better game and don't care for online multiplayer, get Stardrive 2 its superior in almost every way.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												So let’s review Master of Orion, the rebooted offering from NGD studios. I have a love hate relationship with 4x games and often get the feeling that they all offer the same gaming experience. You get tech trees, alien species, anomaly bonus crates and a thin veneer of a story which is fluffed out by how you go about your galactic business. Weather it’s uniting factions with your diplomatic hippy powers or crushing your enemy’s with fleets of alien♥♥♥♥♥♥kicker ships. You can pretty much do as you will. Master of Orion or Moo as it’s funny acronymic title is okay for a 4x title. I see it as more of an entry level 4x game. It has nice cut scenes, fairly in-depth tactical space battles and a Klingon traitor doing the voice overs. The problem I had with the game is I just couldn’t get in to it. After the first opening moves (or turns) everything just seemed to slot into generic 4x. The thing is I’ve played Distant Worlds which is a huge real time 4x game. Okay DW has graphics that would make a C64 blush but it has enormous depth and customisation. I’m not bashing Moo but just warning seasoned veterans of the genre that Moo in my opinion won’t satiate that galactic empiric feel you get from other 4x titles.So on to the obligatory pros and cons:PROS:Michael DornNice art assets and animationsThe races are pretty well thought out but limitedA solid entry level 4x gameCONS:Generic 4x gameplayPretty limited tech treeNot enough ship and general customisationEvil human race is locked behind paywall? (I could be wrong)I’m giving it a positive review because it does exactly what it says on the tin. The tin is subjective though. It may be a tin of glorious Heinz baked beans ready to be lovingly poured over some toast. Or it’s a tin of all day breakfast that you scarf down after a drinking binge that should have stopped 4 days ago.Cheers!

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												A very welcome update on the original with a few elements missing.Colony LeadersAntarean InvasionsFleet/Ship Leaders Including the Legendary Admiral and his unique shipNo Antarean Defeat VictoryTrilarian race is goneGnolams are goneAntareans are a scrolling marque jokeGetting past that, it's amazing how much was done.  Gone are frieghter fleets, but replaced with a much more effective empire wide distribution network (researchable tech).  Pirates have a much more active role, and can be combated for population or cash rewards.  Ship combat and design is so much more stable and fun than the original 2D combat grid that would constantly lock up or crash even on it's release to GOG/Steam on machines that outclass the 2 decade old release. GNN is one of the best little highlights from the game, and it even has a "no news" filler update in the mix of events that the game can offer.  The tech tree allows for simplified choices, and the race customization is less confusing letting the player have access to the core of aliens races.  You have a great deal of variety in the standard races, and the new point mechanics makes even being a creative race challanging.  I'll definitely be getting the DLC to enjoy this to it's fullest.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												I have held off on doing a review of this title to see how it would evolve. As a long time fan of the original MOO 1&2 and, with sufficient community patches/modifications even MOO 3(to a point), I find that this latest installment of the "franchise" sits squarely as MOO 1.5.Overall colony management et al. is decent. Graphics are above average. Core races are present (though lacking relative to MOO 2 and MOO 3 in quantity and variation/backstory). Music and sound effects are typical of a strategy title. The UI is viable with most areas being reasonably intuitive for a 4x design.I find the lack of backstory to be a great detriment to this iteration of MOO. Other titles, even MOO 3, had a greater atmosphere in terms of racial distinctiveness--there was a feel of something more vs. a generic 4x that's founded on an excellent series.Though I have never been a hard set fan of leaders, certainly their absense from this product is clearly a detriment--as previous titles in the series and many modern competitors (Stellaris) have such implemented.Space battles are a very curious beast. They lack the hands on control and tactics of MOO 1 & 2, but are more fluid than the system utilised in MOO 3. The bias towards long ranged weaponry, ala MOO 3, remains and the lack of tight hands on tactical control (to the degree of MOO 2) has me often gearing fleets for autoresolution rather than for any sort of finesse (which makes me think of combat in Spaceward Ho!).Overall, however, development has continued. Additional content has been added and many bugs have been fixed. Though this title is far from complete/polished, continued improvements are clearly evident. This, with the nostalgia of the MOO universe/franchise, makes me optimistic as to the true "end product" that will be generated.I recommend this title to anyone who is a fan of the MOO franchise--there is enough here, and the promise of more, to afford fans of the MOO series and enjoyable experience. For others who are not veterans of the franchise I would advise waiting to see if the new DLC content is enough to flush out the core options to make this, functionally, more on par with Stellaris (which is curently a more complete 4x experience without MOO nostalgia).

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												As a long-time fan of the Master of Orion series, I'll admit was I pretty hesitant about picking up this remake/reboot/whatever you want to call it. Some of the decisions made by the devs didn't sit well with me at all, but I finally decided to give the game a fair go.Before I start - I'm reviewing MOO + the Antares DLC, and I'm running the 5X mod. These both impact my overall impression of the game.I'm happy to say that my experiences with the game so far have been mostly positive. I loved the turn-based combat of the original MOO series, but I have to admit that running battles in real-time allows for a fairer outcome, rather than the "wipe-the-opposite-fleet-off-the-map-before-they-get-a-chance-to-shoot" scenarios I quite often had in MOO2, and was almost always able to take advantage of in the late-game.The overhaul of the espionage system with the DLC was a definite step in the right direction.This might not be the MOO that hard-core fans wanted, but this is definitely the most fun I've had in a space-based 4X game since the days of MOO2. There are aspects I'm not entirely fond of, such as star-lanes, the Antaran's obesession with me in every game, the mod menu working whenever it decides it wants to, and the fact that I have to make use of a mod to get a decent balanced game.There are bugs that crop up from time to time, and the game tends to slow down pretty drastically as you get closer to your turn-limit. I tend to let the AI take care of space battles because once there are enough ships on the screen managing all of them becomes a massive pain.If you had to ask me whether I would recommend the game - I would say yes. It's not everything I hoped for, but it ticks most of the right boxes for me, personally. There are still many areas in which the game can improve, and hopefully the devs will work on some of these.If reading this review still doesn't make you decide one way or another, I'd recommend waiting for the next sale, and grabbing it then.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2016
												First off, I am ashamed to say I haven't played the original Master of Orion game (I sadly missed back in the day, and have had too much on my plate since to give it a play. I hope to rectify this problem soon). However, I have played Stellaris, the Galactic Civ games, Sins of a Solar Empire, Endless Space, and several similar games, so I feel comfortable talking about this genre.What I enjoy most about this game are the personalities of the alien races (I've played as humans and Balrathi and enjoyed both), the presentation (the space battles are exciting, the art is nice, and the music is really good). Even though I'm not planning to play through another match anytime soon, I did have enough fun learning the ropes to recommend it on that basis.There are, however, some negatives, especially for those familiar with the other games I mentioned. For instance, troops and ships do not gain experience or level up, nor are commanders or admirals that level up as in Heroes of M&M. True, you can upgrade ships as you learn new techs, but the lack of an experience mechanic meant that I never felt much emotion for the ships in my fleets. I have become used to being very protective of my military in other games (such as Civ) for this reason, and I missed the mechanic here.Secondly, I am concerned about the difficulty level. I played two "huge" maps on normal difficulty, and in both games, the pirates were so puny as to be a mere nuisance. Likewise, when I encountered the aliens, I was able to easily conquer them. I'd like to flatter myself by saying it's because I'm such a pro, but, alas, I know this isn't the case. I should've been defeated or at least seriously challenged until I had properly learned the game. To be able to win so easily was a downer for me (and, yes, I know there are higher difficulties, but to me "normal" should be a baseline, and I don't like the idea of handicapping myself to compensate for a poor AI). I was never able to use my "Doom Star" or death star ship, either--another minor gripe. By the time I was able to build this juggernaut, the game was over.Thirdly, the game feels underdeveloped in some key ways. This is most obvious during land invasions. I can excuse an indie dev for limiting such sequences to a static screen, but here it just feels cheap. If the game offered more compelling planet invasions (or at least a handful of nice cut scenes like the ones for the colony ship landings), I'd be more forgiving. But towards the end, I felt like I was just killing time until my troop ships finally arrived on the scene. Finally, I think there are just too many techs. The tech tree is extensive, but not nearly as finely honed as Civ. There was always something to look forward to that would make a difference in gameplay, but there were simply too many that just offered minor stat upgrades. I slowed down the learning pace in my settings just to keep from being distracted by them (as well as the GCN broadcasts). I would rather have a third fewer techs and have the remaining ones thus be more important and hard-earned.Overall, though, I enjoyed this game, but I must admit that I prefer some of the games I mentioned before. If you're bored with Civ, Gal Civ, dislike the "sector" mechanic in Stellaris, the real-time of Sins, etc., definitely consider this game. I can't speak to how well it captures the magic of the original Master of Orion, but I tend to doubt it since that game is widely regarded as a seminal game of the genre. In short, I don't regret my purchase, but I don't feel enough was done to really set this game apart and make it something truly special.

												Thank you for a fine game.  I have tried to play at least six or seven space based games over the past 20 years. number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												I am a huge fan of the 4X genre. MoO2 is one of my favorite games of all time. MoO4 has done the series and the genre justice. If you liked MoO2, there is no reason you will not like this game. My only disappointments are the fact that the trillarians and elerians are not in the game, and that there are star lanes. However, the presence of star lanes is tolerable, and actually works quite well for the game the way it was designed. Without them, outposts and scanners would serve no purpose, so in that regard I think it was a resonable adjustment to give the game some distinction.Everything else is excellent. Diplomacy is good. Espionage is good (seriously, they did a great job with it, it is better than any other MoO game in terms of espionage). The combat is good. I, for one, enjoy real time combat over turn based. Turn based combat worked for MoO2 back in the day because of the power of computers. In this day and age, real time does better and offers more interactivity. Most of the core aspects of the game are still the same as MoO2 with only some minor adjustments, fresh technologies, and modernization. I love the technology tree, it has very sensible choices, and still retains the aspect of MoO2 where you had to make choices between technologies while bringing the technology tree of MoO2 more into the 21st century. All in all, it is worth your money. Support the developer, they did a good job. I paid for this to be a reboot of MoO2, and it is exactly that, with all the flavor you'd expect.Overall: 9/10Side Note: Add Trillarians and Elerians as DLC, and it would probably be worth a 10/10 for the effort of rebooting a legendary franchise and not making the reboot suck.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												As someone unfamiliar with the past of Masters of Orion and a newcomer to the series, I have to say that I've really enjoyed what I've played so far. It's basically Civilization in space, with very colorful and distinct races, exploration/combat/tech trees. The main distinction is the overlying goal to reach Orion, a legendary planet populated by an advanced race. Other goals for victory are the typical ones we're used to..Diplomacy/Combat/Economy.What struck me about the game is the amount of polish that went into it..I honestly had no idea Wargaming was developing this title and they've done a fantastic job fleshing out the world and giving distinct flavor to each race. Some are more keen to combat, others are more predisposed to economy, while a few are downright unpredictable and unstable.The art and animation is fantastic. They even went so far as to add fully fleshed out space battles you can manually control with cinematic angles (Although auto resolve will be the solution 95% of the time). The dialogue with the races is really cool, and having to keep in mind the nuances of each race versus the planets you colonize also gives the game depth I haven't encountered before.I've been having fun with it so far, but I do wish there was some campaign element. However, I've had a ton of fun creating my own narratives as my empires have prospered (And crumbled mostly) in this colorful scifi strategy title. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2
												Have you ever wanted a Master Of Orion game that gave MOO2 the JJ Abrams treatment? Me either, but that's what Master Of Orion (4) is. It's got more than 2/3 of the features from MOO2, more than 2/3 of the playable races (by default), and over half the fun. It's the most logical reaction the developers could've had to the critical reception of the catastrophically boring, unpolished, yet innovative and deep MOO3.I often get the impression that the voice cast is so great (you'll recognize voices from Borderlands and Invader Zim, for example) because of the development team's apparent "homage to MOO2" approach to designing this game. And you could say the same thing about the graphics. The musical score is forgettable, but importantly, fits the tone of the game and isn't intrusive enough to become irritating when repeatedly played. There was clearly a lot of thought behind the animating of the various characters, for that matter. The lighting, as odd as it is for a turn-based strategy game to have noteworthy lighting, adds a charming tone to the visuals. It's the most grandiose and beautiful monument to MOO2 that's ever been constructred... which is of middling consolation for its fans.The gameplay, though, is functionally identical to Master Of Orion 2, other than the parts that were removed. Some of them are being added back into the game through patches. The tactical combat isn't as.... glaringly absent as before, due to a series of patches. The other races, evidently, are going to be added back into the game via DLC in 3-packs. No announcement (that I know of) has been made about the possible return of the Imsaes, Ithkul, or Evon to the game, or of any of the other races from previous MOOs. And the fun can be added back in through mods, to a surprising extent. There's a custom race option, but the balance is still botched (custom races are always objectively, statistically inferior to non-custom races, *which both sucks and blows at the same time), and hopefully will undergo yet another overhaul before a final version is settled on. And so far, we've got neither the delightful ground combat animations of MOO2 nor the delightful ground combat radio drama of MOO3.So do I recommend this game? Sorta. This is a textbook example of a review that would've benefitted from a "sideways thumb" option. If you've got a lot of disposable income and you're sitting on the fence about this purchase, I'd encourage you to give it a chance. It's by no means a bad game. It's average. It doesn't make me worry for the future of the series, nor is it entertaining enough to compete with MOO2 and Sins Of A Solar Empire for my attention. It's definitely possible for a game with so much post-launch work behind it to eventually become even better than MOO2, especially with mod support (which it has), but it's clearly not there yet. For now it's a shallow but reasonably well-crafted Master Of Orion sequel. Its foundations are sturdy, its facade pictureque, and its insides unfurnished and empty. Yeah... that'll do. You get the idea.*Edited for clarity

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												Master of Orion was one of the first computer games I bought when I built my first DOS computer back in the middle 90's. I loved it. Master of Orion 2 was even better. MOO3? Well, if you can't say something nice...I've played a lot of 4X space games but few ever recaptured that magic of MOO I & II. Until this one. This new reboot of Master of Orion is not "old wine in new bottles". It's new life altogether. If you have ever played any of the old titles, particularly MOO2 you will be able to jump right into this. The learning curve is easy and the game is complex without being complicated. The interface is clean and easy to navigate and the cinematic space battles are a joy to both watch and play out. It is not perfect. It does not have the customizability of the Galactic Civ games I'm sorry to say and it would be nice to see new races and hull types added as future DLC. I'd certainly buy them. But like their predecessors this game does have heart and soul and that indefinable something that drives all 4X gamers to say "just one more turn". If you have never played a Master of Orion game this one is well worth your time. If you have then don't hesitate. All your old friends are here: the Darloks, Meklar, Klackons, Bulrathi, and all the others who kept you awake long into the night fifteen years ago. They are waiting to say "hello" once again!

Posted: September 25, 2016
												I'd call this a solid, space 4x. It does nothing really new - and nothing spectacular but most of the parts are well executed. If your expectations aren't too high then this is a game that can provide a satisfying amount of 4x gameplay. The unfortunate thing is I think this could have moved from a "good" game to a very good one if they had:- done something interesting with the battle system. The current implementation gives you so little control that I auto resolve almost every time. That is in sharp contrast to the very involvng battles of MOO2.- fleshed out the spy system. Right now dealing with spies is almost like busywork and could have offered so much more. Why not let spies level up - and make them more hard to recruit (it feels like spy spamming right now).Here's hoping the dev will improve these areas and others because it's a pretty good game to start that could be even better.

												I would recommend this game, particularly to 4X newbies who want to cut their teeth in the genre. The gameplay is accessible yet can be deep – has a low skill floor and high skill ceiling.It is highly polished graphically and in terms of sound assets (great voice acting talent bar none) and the fluff story of each race is lovingly re-created from MoO2 days of yore. The race customisation screen has most of the MoO2 staples like Creative, Lithovore etc. My only hesitation so far was in that the game still has a few bugs – I mean other than the Klackon - on my rig but the devs have been very keen to interact and help address any issues the community flagged to them. This gives me confidence in the long term prospects of the game.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												I am going to do something I do not normally do, I am going to review a game.  Though, in all honesty, this is more a review of the game company then of the game itself.  When I heard there was a new Master of Orion game coming, I was estatic.  I have many fond memories of all the MoO games, I enjoyed all of them, even 3......And here we were getting a new game!  Then I realized the way gaming companies are now a days, games get released halfway done, lazy programming and shoddy quality checking along with excellerated deadlines is the norm for most game developers today.  And I have always blamed the system more then the people in the system itself.  But enough of that BS.  The new Master of Orion game did something, and has continued to do something, that I have not seen in a development crew for a long time.  It impresses.  I love this game.  It's fun.  And that is why people buy games....To have fun.  But I have seen a commitment in the new MoO game that I dont think I've ever seen in a development company.  They keep working to make this game the best that it can be.  You may not agree with every choice made, but they have been willing to make it.  There have been a ton of games abandoned after being finished.  MoO is definently NOT one of those games.  And for that reason alone, I recommend buying this game.

												Before there was Galactic Civilizations, there was , for a great many of us, Masters of Orion. This was the trailblazing game for this type of strategy game for those of us who love them most.I, for one, am simply delighted to see it updated, yet kept more or less true to the the original.Is it the equivalent of Galactic CivilizationsII, or even 2 or 1? Of course not. Nor should we excpect it to be. No matter what is done to update it, if it is to remain true to the original, then it cannot be more than  it was at its core, without making it a whole new game.If you want to do that, then just look at the complete disaster that was Masters of Orion III, perhaps the most disastrous sequel to a game that was ever released!No, I say this is a delightful little trip down memory lane and totally enjoyable if you approach it as what it actually is....an updated version of the same game that it was, with better graphics, better voices more amusing scenes, etc. I love it!Once they get the rest of the bugs worked out (and you know they will), mods will make it have endless variations and I look  forward to the inevitable revival and endless websites to come!Now, SOMEBODY GET BUSY AND POST SOME CHEATS!!!!! please???

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												I feel after a half dozen games that there are still problems that need ironing out. I love the game.. I have played every incarnation of MOO since it came out. I am not an expert but in the past have always played at the 'normal' difficulty or one harder and dont reasonably alright.In this incarnation, I have had difficulties and not sure why. The diplomacy is very one sided in my experience.  The AI always seems to want much more than they offer.. even the races like the Klackons and Silicoids that are supposed to be repulsive and suffer a minus to diplomatic negotiations. Which is hilarious if you think about it.. what makes a race repulsive to a galaxy of differing life forms?I don't care for the spy system.  It just doesn't feel right. Im constantly harrased by them shutting down research and production for 10 turns or poisoning my food. Having anti spies everwhere does not seem to help. I have not tried the Darloks yet so I have never gotten past gathering data with anyone; while they are constanlty crippling my planets.  Its just 'uninteresting' to me.The graphics are nice... not what I look for in a 4x game, but it really is *cool* to have large fleet battles having my destroyers taking out all the AI frigs whilst my cruisers hurl heavy missile fire on their capital ships.  The DOOM star is f-ing EPIC! Using Guardian weapons is great too. The 'State of the Galaxy' stuff was interesting the first couple of times.. kinda funny seeing the antics of that male? robot anchor.  But now I just skip it because I can see the info in the victory path screen.The differing ships for each race is nice. The Silicoid rock ships and the classic 50's UFO shapes of the Psilons...Tactical battles are fun. Don't ever let the computer figure it out for you. I am not sure what more I could want from the game... it isn't MOO2 but its nice. If they fix some of the imbalances, make the diplomac and espionage more engaging some how... I still highly recommend the game even with some of its, ummmm.. lets say small disappointments for any fans of 4x games.  For the publisher... Im sorry, but I won't be paying $20 just to get the Terrans. I already paid for Moo1, Moo2 and Moo3. So the 'collector package' is not an enticement.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												Tried the different maps and each one requires a slightly different play style or strategy.  Each race has slightly different bonus or ability but mostly all have same goal,  get planets, beat other races for most population.  More population means more money or research or ships or whatever you want to win. Realtime combat is fun and works, no bugs yet.  Only everyone has same options for tech and weapons.The differences being in whether you pick item a or item b after researching a box, but you can trade for the tech you don't choose with friendly ai.   AI does some wonky things but is mostly sound in their empire building.  The races who get fast growth are usually tougher to beat since they have larger fleets and mass quanity usually beats quality.Some things to make the game deeper imo ..............Resources ....  generic manufacturing resources can be broken down so that you can harvest said resources or not....i.e. wood, food,  metal, rare metal, energy, exotic space elements ect. instead of mine, big mine, bigger mine to build anything and everything.   Farms harvest food, so why not wood cutters, mines, manufactucting, and assembly plants ect. to deepen the building of fleets and weapons to keep it from being a game about quantity over quality. Human race survives better because of diplomacy and staying out of untimely wars.  Research, and stealth aren't nearly as competative to mass quanity right now. Research.....split up research tree's to keep it from being a 'research everything first' ftw.....Being really good with lasers and,  energy should be competative  to expert mass drivers and armour builders but researching both takes too much time.  Have a separate tree for racial only benefits and society perks.  Phylon gets their own science building techs, Humans get diplomacy techs, Bulrathing get terraforming techs, Crag get elemental harvesting techs, ect...Also, variety of planets would add to depth,  most any planet can be made into Gia .... 8-/

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15
												Well, what people say is true. The developers abandoned a relatively big name title that I think everyone was hoping would slowly be patched back to life. Maybe we can hope they're working on a DLC? I'd buy it, strategy games are still mostly niche so I'd rather support them and see if they can fix this game even if it costs more.Does the game stall for long times between turns? Yes. Are some parts completely broken? Eh, yeah kinda I suppose. Is the realtime combat part a piece of utter♥♥♥♥♥♥ YES YES YES IT'S LIKE SOMEONE'S FIRST GAME THEY EVER MADE. It's bizarre and jarring since the rest of the game is so polished visually, and then you have this early access looking thing for ship combat. You have to nurse it as if you're playing League of Legends, constantly clicking the mouse and repeating orders. It sucks because even though you can skip the realtime parts entirely, the automatic calculations aren't in your favor even when you should win a battle, so it's better to do it the realtime way.One of the complaints I hear the most that is more subtle, is that the game just isn't very strategic. Funny for a strategy game. Well, this is VERY TRUE. It's much more like an arcade game in a strategy game's clothes. The planning and thinking are as shallow as dish water, it's mostly just about gathering up the strength to throw all you can at the enemies, and with mind control letting you steal a planet instantly with one click, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ monkey smoking a hookah could beat this game.BUT ... it's a pretty dang fun arcade game. The news broadcasts are funny, the lines the characters say are filled with cute geek references and stuff like that, and the visual polish feels like watching an animated movie at its best moments. I think the problem is that too many hardcore strategy fans bought this and thought it was bad, but it's more for someone who wants a relatively simple stress-relief game that they don't have to think too hard about when they're playing. It's cheetos, not filet mignon.So, uh... honestly, for that, I recommend it. It's great to blow off some steam and play something that has the dance moves of a more complicated game but goes easy on you even at the highest difficulty levels. Hah, I just realized something while writing this - you know what it's like? One of those clicker games, like Cookie Clicker and all of those! Just with a bit more structure. You click your way to victory meeting funny characters along the way. Is it worth $30? For the amazing animation quality and beautiful music I say yes, yes it actually is.Insanely high production values black-sheep game that everyone hated, would play it any time I need something simple and stupid. 10/10 for what it actually is (instead of what it was hyped to be, mostly by the fans). If you can stand the idea without getting angry that someone turned a venerable strategy franchise into a shiny glorified version of Galcon/Dyson/other casual smartphone-style games, yeah, you'll have a nice time.I truly believe the developers had a vision, but it wasn't one that most people wanted, and so people just labeled it bad because of that. But it's not that they made Master of Orion "wrong" to me, it's that they made their own game that does its own thing. Things get reinvented all the time, and I feel like maybe the developers felt there were enough dry and deep 4X games out there, and made a more lighthearted Cartoon Network style one on purpose. The performance issues on computers with slower CPUs probably didn't help either, but if you keep it down to 5 opponents or so and have a recent i7, it's fine. If it's okay for a chess simulator to take a while to decide on a move, it ought to be okay here too.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												This game is not Master of Orion.Yes, I am one of those who played the original games years ago.Ok, so it is not Master of Orion, but it is a good 4X space strategy.This game feels more like a combination of Endless Space and Galactic Civilizations, with a very dull real-time combat where you cannot change the outcome much. Doesn't matter if you just watch the battle or command the ships yourself. Now, the real-time combat can be done right. For example StarDrive 2 has significantly better real-time combat where you can actually change the tide of battle by moving the ships smart. Even Endless Spaces' autocombat system feels better than this.So yes, this is the biggest problem for me with the game. It lacks the turn-based combat that made the original two Master of Orions so great, and it does the real-time combat all wrong. I can handle the changes in the travel system (star lanes like Endless Space) or the (way too) slow game pace, and the tedious espionage system. But the combat system is just.. meh.However, I do like the game. The poor combat system does not kill ALL the fun for me. I enjoy the colonizing & research phase of the game.If you like Endless Space, then you should get this game on sale. I do not think this game is worth its full price, but on sale? Definately.If I had to give a rating, I'd say 7/10.It's pretty good, but it's not great. And it's definately not Master of Orion.They had the budget to hire well known voice actors; why didn't they hire Steve Barcia and Ken Burd to oversee the project? Maybe next time.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												I've been a fan of the MOO series since it came out.  Certainly not a "die hard" fan, but I played all the games, and would rank them in my top 5 strategy games of all time.I was hesitant to purchase this game based on many reviews, but I do really enjoy it.  I do believe it's shelf life is relatively short unless they bring out some major updates or expansions soon.  Some of the positives that I really enjoy about this game is that games go rather quickly.  I enjoy the level of management meaning.  I don't enjoy games that bog me down in the details of every thing.  Ship design is done well to keep it easy, but there are enough choices that need to be made to make it interesting.  The game is beautiful, and the voice acting is pretty good.My primary negative is that the races don't feel all that different.  I also think that custom races start with too few points.  I think if they gave custom races 2 more points it would retain balance, and make the game more fun by being able to design your own take on the races.I can see myself putting another 10-30 hours into this game, and then revisiting from time to time because of how easy it is to pick up and play.

												I love this game. Coming to the space 4x genre as an avid Civilization player I found a lot of the games to be dry and unintuitive. Masters of Orion though, is intuitive and genuinley exciting as well as having depth and intersting choices. I'm still getting my head around the combat. Here are some features I absolutley love:A terrifying alien race that raids the lead player periodically as a balencing mechanic.An interesting balencing act between production and pollution so your capital isn't able to pump out everything in the game in one turn come late game.The ability to build Death star equivalent mega weapons and decimate all who oppose you. I'm not a veteran Masters of Orion player and I'm told this game doesn't bring a lot new to the genre, but everything it does bring is laid out in an intuative and visually stunning way. So if you are new to space 4x or simply want to enjoy an epic space opera than I cannot recomend this game highly enough.

												Where to begin on this one? I picked it up the day it was released, liked it okay, but was slightly let down as an old time fan of the original series. Then Stellaris happened and I forgot all about this game. Which turned out to work in favor of this reboot for me. Master of Orion operates in a different space than Stellaris for many reasons. Presentation is top notch, and I often find myself lost in the environment. While the game is much more simple than others in the genre, it still presents quite a challenge. Some reviews mention the game crashing at ~500 turns, but i've never experienced anything more than a couple of extra seconds. I enjoy the pace, espeically if you decide to crank up the game speed. All in all i would give it an 8/10. If you enjoy 4x space games, and want something new, I would recommend. Pros: excellent voice actingbeautiful graphicsinspiring musiclikeable raceslots of polishCons:shallow space battles

content:
Posted: February 6
												I am not sure why so many people have disliked this game. I love it. I also am a good mix of heavy gamer in some respects, but also I am a casual gamer in other respects. In regards to Orion here I am the latter. This is an easy game to play with amusing voice acting, and simple gameplay. Mods are also fun to play around with. This game can satisfy my need for sci-fi elements without creating a lot of stress to do so. I like that you can make it a short game, or a long one, depending on how you set the game up. Each race is amusing, I prefer the Psilon people, as they are more peaceful and discovery oriented. It's paced well, and if it's not fast enough for you the settings will help that. Beautiful graphics. It makes me feel like a god manipulating the fate of a universe. I can spend 7 hours, or 7 minutes and still get the same satisfaction consistently. Bottom line is it's easy to catch on with, play, and balance your time. If you like sci-fi, I'd highly recommend this game to anyone.
